Formal Supplement

Unique Factorization Domain Axiom

Axiom (UFD): Let ğ’° be a category with finite products and a distinguished set of irreducible objects P. We require:

  1. Every nonâ€‘unit object Xâˆˆğ’° admits a finite decomposition X â‰… pâ‚âˆ˜â€¦âˆ˜pâ‚– with páµ¢âˆˆP.
  2. This decomposition is unique: if X â‰… qâ‚âˆ˜â€¦âˆ˜qâ‚˜ is another, then m=k and there is a permutation Ïƒ with qáµ¢â‰…pâ‚Ïƒ(i)â‚.

Category-Theoretic Formalization

Model ğ’° as a monoidal category (with âˆ˜ as tensor product). Intrinsic primes are the atoms in its subobject lattice. The prime coordinate map Ï† is a strong monoidal functor Ï†: (ğ’°,âˆ˜,1) â†’ (â„¤^(P),+,0), preserving tensor and unit.

Precisely, Ï†(Xâˆ˜Y)=Ï†(X)+Ï†(Y), Ï†(1)=0, and Ï† is initial among all such homomorphisms (universal property): any other functor to an abelian group factors uniquely through Ï†.

Sheaf & Stack Perspective

Observers form a fibered category (stack) over ğ’°: assign to each X the groupoid of frames R. The total category Eâ‚‚ has objects (X,r) and morphisms only in frames. The canonical frame section Ïƒ: Xâ†¦(X,râ‚€) exhibits Eâ‚‚ as a trivial torsor, ensuring global coherence and flatness of the bundle.

Extensions to Dedekind Domains

In a domain lacking unique factorization (e.g., â„¤[âˆšâˆ’5]), one refines primes to prime ideals. Working in the category of fractional ideals restores the UFD axiom: every ideal factors uniquely. The UOR coordinate extends to the ideal class group, encoding ideal exponents in the prime ideal basis.

Baseâ€‘Absolute Prime Coordinates

Definition: A coordinate system is baseâ€‘absolute if it is canonical and independent of any chosen basis or chart. The UOR prime coordinate Ï† is baseâ€‘absolute: it does not depend on numeral base, vector space basis, or presentation. It is intrinsic to the object's structure.

Primary Decomposition in Modules

For modules over Noetherian rings, primary decomposition generalizes prime factorization. Each submodule decomposes into intersections of primary submodules, yielding coordinates in the lattice of primary components. A coherence metric may rank decompositions by simplicity.

Universal Properties & Limits of UOR

Ï† enjoys a universal mapping property: any functor from ğ’° to a graded abelian group preserving composition factors through Ï†. UOR is the terminal coordinate system under this constraint.

Case Studies in Pure Math

  • Polynomial Rings: Ï† maps f(x) to exponent vector of irreducible factors, enabling gcd/lcm of polynomials by componentwise min/max.
  • Algebraic Number Theory: Ï† on ideals tracks ramification exponents in Galois extensions, unifying decomposition groups and Frobenius actions.
  • Group Representation: Decompose representations into irreducibles; assign coordinate of multiplicities, turning tensor products into vector addition.
